match.answertext: trees and make the park smaller.

match.answertext: wants the others to talk to other people in the park.

question.name: Environment 2
question.questiontext:
Complete the sentences with the words below.

1. It is very important to [[1]] water.
2. You should really buy [[2]] food.
3. I never take the [[3]] provided at the supermarket.
4. We always take glass bottles to the bottle bank and [[4]] them.
5. Only [[5]] leave bottles and cans on the beach.
6. People shouldn't drive short [[6]], they should use their bikes or walk.

question.name: Word Formation
question.questiontext:
1. By 11:00 I felt so tiring / [tired] that I went to bed.

2. I heard the film was good, but it was very [disappointing] /disappointed.

3. Tim gets [bored] / boring if he has to study too much.

4. It is very confused / [confusing] to be taught in so many classrooms.

5. Cycling to school has one [disadvantage] / advantage. It makes you feel hot and sweaty.

6. Because of the disunderstanding / [misunderstanding], half the class went to the wrong classroom.

7. My alarm clock didn't go off, and so I outsleep / [overslept] this morning.

8. Ming decided to [underline] / outline all the important words in the text.

9. Most people have no believe / [belief] in ghosts.

10. Eddie put the [frozen] / freeze food in the freezer.

11. Our teacher was really [angry] / anger when she found out.

12. You have to have a lot of patient / [patience] to go fishing.

question.name: Grammar practice (reported speech)
question.questiontext:
Part 1
Choose the correct option.

1. He {#1} that he doesn't speak English very well.
2. They {#2} they were Spanish.
3. She {#3} she wasn't coming. 
4. He {#4} he wanted more rice.


Part 2
Complete the sentences.

1. "I'm hungry," said Peter.
  Peter said that {#5}.
2. "We're going home," Jenny told me.
  Jenny told me {#6}.
3. "I'm not hungry," said Sue.
  Sue {#7}.
4. "You are tired!" she told us.
  She {#8}.
5. "He has finished his homework," says May.
  May {#9}.

question.name: Grammar practice (reported speech)
question.questiontext: {1:SHORTANSWER:=they're going home~=they are going home~=that they are going home~=they were going home}

question.name: Grammar practice (reported speech)
question.questiontext: {1:SHORTANSWER:=said that she's not hungry~=said that she is not hungry~=said she isn't hungry~=said that she isn't hungry~=said that she wasn't hungry~=said she wasn't hungry}

answer.answertext: said that she is not hungry

question.name: Grammar practice (reported speech)
question.questiontext: {1:SHORTANSWER:=told us that we are tired~=told us that we're tired=told us we are tired~=told us we're tired~=told us that we were tired~=told us we were tired<span style="background-color: transparent;">}

answer.answertext: told us that we are tired
told us that we're tired=told us we are tired
told us that we were tired
told us we were tired<span style="background-color: transparent;">

question.name: Grammar practice (reported speech)
question.questiontext: {1:SHORTANSWER:=said he has finished his homework~=said that he has finished his homework~=said that he has finished his homework~=said that he had finished his homework~=said he had finished his homework}

answer.answertext: said he has finished his homework
said that he has finished his homework
said that he has finished his homework
said that he had finished his homework
said he had finished his homework

question.name: Greenpeace (R & U Of E Part 1)
question.questiontext:
Read the following article about the environment group Greenpeace and decide which answer best fits each gap.

Greenpeace

Greenpeace is an independent organisation that campaigns to {#1} the environment. It has approximately 4.5 million members worldwide in 158 countries, 300, 000 of these in the United Kingdom. {#2} in North America in 1971, it has since opened offices round the world. As {#3} as its campaigning {#4}, it also has a charitable trust which {#5} scientific research and {#6} educational projects on environmental issues. Greenpeace {#7} in non-violet direct action. Activists {#8} public attention to serious threats to the environment. {#9} issues on which the organisation is campaigning include the atmosphere (global warming), the {#10} of the rainforests and toxic {#11} being emitted from factories. Greenpeace is committed to the principles of political independence and internationalism. By exposing {#12} to the environment and in working to {#13} solutions, Greenpeace has no permanent allies or enemies.

question.name: Reading and Use of English (Part 3)
question.questiontext:
For questions 1-10, read the text below. Use the word given in capitals  to form a word that fits in the gap. There is an example at the beginning.


POLLUTING THE ENVIRONMENT

Oil on beaches, vehicle exhaust fumes, litter and many other waste (0) PRODUCTS (PRODUCE) are called pollutants, because they pollute our environment. Pollutants can affect our health and harm animals and plants. Releasing (1) {#1} (CHEMIST) waste from factories and power stations is one of the main ways in which we pollute our (2) {#2} (SURROUND). These waste substances are the (3) {#3} (WANT) results of modern living.

Pollution itself is not new - a hundred years ago factories sent out great clouds of (4) {#4} (POISON) smoke and (5) {#5} (FORTUNATE}, pollution has spread to the land, air and water of every corner of our planet. Our (6){#6} (SCIENCE) have much to learn about pollution, but we do know more about how to control it. The use of solar energy, instead of coal and gas, will help in the fight as it is very much cleaner than fossil fuels. We can also achieve some (7) {#7} (REDUCE) in pollution by recycling waste and using biodegradable materials which eventually break down in the soil and (8){#8} (APPEAR).

The use of cars which run on (9) {#9} (ELECTRIC) instead of petrol is also a key feature in the fight against pollution. It is up to everyone to be as (10) {#10} (ECONOMIC) as they can with the Earth's limited resources.

essay.graderinfo:
Answers should be graded on following factors,

  • The answer should be unique and cannot be copied from any source,
  • Score should be allotted on the basis of vocabulary used and language skills displayed.

'Effects of modern urban lifestyle on health and well-being'
